update.description:
This is another piece out of pull request #2633, but done a little better. It adds a way to query the capabilities of a physics engine.

Capabilities that can be queried are `CATEGORY_BITS` and `COLLIDE_BITS`, which are needed for fixing #1564. All four physics engines default to returning `false` if a capability is unknown.

* Adds `PhysicsEngine::Capability` enum
* Adds `virtual bool PhysicsEngine::Supports(Capability)`
* Adds a simple test checking if Supports() throws
update.title: Added support for querying a physics engine's capabilities
update.reason: Shelving until priority of solving #1564 increases.

pull_request.title: Added support for querying a physics engine's capabilities

pullrequest.title: Added support for querying a physics engine's capabilities

content.raw:
It's intended for gazebo plugins that want to use an alternate strategy if the physics engine doesn't support a particular feature.

Specifically it is for #1564. Currently the CPU Ray sensor projects rays starting at minimum range. The bug is they see inside of geometry that gets too close. With collide_bitmask this can be fixed by starting from the sensor origin and masking out the laser geometry in its way. Problem is on physics engines that don't support collide_bitmask the rays from the sensor would strike the inside of the lidar geometry. With this API the ray sensor can default to the old behavior on other physics engines.
content.html:
It's intended for gazebo plugins that want to use an alternate strategy if the physics engine doesn't support a particular feature.

Specifically it is for #1564. Currently the CPU Ray sensor projects rays starting at minimum range. The bug is they see inside of geometry that gets too close. With collide_bitmask this can be fixed by starting from the sensor origin and masking out the laser geometry in its way. Problem is on physics engines that don't support collide_bitmask the rays from the sensor would strike the inside of the lidar geometry. With this API the ray sensor can default to the old behavior on other physics engines.

content.raw:
Just one thing about waiting for the SDF pull request to be merged before making a pull request to Gazebo. Personally, I think it's best if these pull requests are reviewed side-by-side. 

In the past, there have been occasions when we merged a new tag to SDFormat but never got to implement the Gazebo side of things. This means we have tags in SDFormat without a reference implementation or a clear documentation stating that it is not supported by Gazebo. A notorious case is reference frames (#1982).
content.html:
Just one thing about waiting for the SDF pull request to be merged before making a pull request to Gazebo. Personally, I think it's best if these pull requests are reviewed side-by-side.

In the past, there have been occasions when we merged a new tag to SDFormat but never got to implement the Gazebo side of things. This means we have tags in SDFormat without a reference implementation or a clear documentation stating that it is not supported by Gazebo. A notorious case is reference frames (#1982).

pullrequest.title: Added support for querying a physics engine's capabilities

content.raw:
That's a really good idea. It looks like category bits aren't quite supported. I'll set category bits to false on all engines for this PR.

I've made a [PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/318/added-to-16-surface-contact-parameters/diff) to get a `<category_bitmask>` tag in sdformat. Once that goes through I'll make another PR to gazebo to properly support them in the earliest version I can. If this PR is merged by then I'll update the Supports() methods on the physics engines that pass a test for category bits support
content.html:
That's a really good idea. It looks like category bits aren't quite supported. I'll set category bits to false on all engines for this PR.

I've made a PR to get a <category_bitmask> tag in sdformat. Once that goes through I'll make another PR to gazebo to properly support them in the earliest version I can. If this PR is merged by then I'll update the Supports() methods on the physics engines that pass a test for category bits support

content.html:
Can this test be expanded with something like:

bool result = physics->Supports(physics::PhysicsEngine::COLLIDE_BITS);
EXPECT_TRUE(_physicsEngine != "simbody" && result);
EXPECT_FALSE(_physicsEngine == "simbody" && result);

pullrequest.title: Added support for querying a physics engine's capabilities

content.raw:
An idea would be to only mark that a physics engine supports a capability when there is a passing test for it. Many times, having code that uses the capability does not mean it actually works or that it won't be broken in the future.

I believe that both collide and category bits are untested features.
content.html:
An idea would be to only mark that a physics engine supports a capability when there is a passing test for it. Many times, having code that uses the capability does not mean it actually works or that it won't be broken in the future.

I believe that both collide and category bits are untested features.
